docs.lead_paragraph: Jill Chaifetz, a lawyer who as the executive director of the nonprofit legal group Advocates for Children of New York turned it into a force for reform in the nation's largest school system, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. She was 41. The cause was ovarian cancer, her brother, Lawrence Chaifetz, said.

headline.main: Jill Chaifetz, Advocate for Students' Rights, Dies at 41

docs.abstract: Jill Chaifetz, Advocates for Children of New York executive director, dies at age 41; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Jill Chaifetz turned the nonprofit legal group Advocates for Children of New York into a force for reform in the nation's largest school system.
docs.section_name: Education; Obituaries; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Half of CBS's schedule on Monday was repeats, but the network won the night anyway. A new episode of ''CSI: Miami'' (19.82 million), starring David Caruso, below, which featured what being shot in the eye might look like and was the most-watched show in prime time, was preceded by Week 2 of Jenna Elfman's sitcom ''Courting Alex.'' Since it followed a rerun of ''Two and a Half Men'' (15.29 million), which delivered a smaller audience than an original episode, ''Alex'' was down from its premiere (13.46 million, versus 14.9 million last week) but retained a good percentage of ''Men'' viewers. Fox was a strong second place for the night in total viewers and adults 18 to 49, with the strangely juxtaposed ''Skating With Celebrities'' (9.93 million) and ''24'' (13.76 million). On WB's soon-to-be-canceled ''7th Heaven,'' Sandy (Haylie Duff) gave birth to a son, and Martin (Tyler Hoechlin) decided to take responsibility for him after being mean throughout the pregnancy. The episode brought in 6.06 million viewers but failed to help the ratings of ''Related,'' which had an audience of a mere 2.42 million. KATE AURTHUR

headline.main: Arts, Briefly; A Shot in the Arm From a Shot in the Eye

docs.abstract: CBS wins Monday night network ratings war with its show CSI: Miami, starring David Caruso; photo (S)
docs.snippet: Half of CBS's schedule on Monday was repeats, but the network won the night anyway. A new episode of ''CSI: Miami'' (19.82 million), starring David Caruso, below, which featured what being shot in the eye might look like and was the most-watched show...

byline.original: By KATE AURTHUR; Compiled by Lawrence Van Gelder

docs.lead_paragraph: Two federal appeals courts yesterday upheld rulings that the Partial Birth Abortion Act, passed by Congress in 2003 but barred by the courts, is unconstitutional because it does not include an exception when the health of a pregnant woman is at risk. The rulings, which came on the same day from three-judge panels in the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in New York, and the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, were substantially based on a United States Supreme Court decision in a Nebraska case in 2000. In that case, the Supreme Court found that any abortion ban must include an exception allowing a procedure that involves a partly delivered fetus after the first trimester of pregnancy, known among opponents as partial birth abortion, when alternative methods could endanger the woman's health.

headline.main: Partial Birth Abortion Act Ruled Unconstitutional by U.S. Courts

docs.abstract: Three-judge panels for Court of Appeals in Second and Ninth Circuits uphold rulings that Partial Birth Abortion Act passed by Congress in 2003 is unconstitutional beause it does not include exception when health of mother is at risk (M)
docs.snippet: The courts upheld rulings that the act is unconstitutional because it doesn't include an exception when a pregnant woman's health is at risk.

docs.lead_paragraph: Joe Jurevicius was pumping gas at a station somewhere in eastern Washington two years ago when the call came. His wife's obstetrician was on the phone from Tampa, Fla. Jurevicius, a Seattle Seahawks wide receiver, has two of the surest hands in the N.F.L., but he said you never would have known it by the way they were shaking. Neither of his two Super Bowl experiences could compare to the anxiety he felt at that moment.

headline.main: This Time, Jurevicius Is Embracing the Game

docs.abstract: Seattle Seahawks receiver Joe Jurevicius prepares for Super Bowl against Pittsburgh Steelers and recalls playing for Tampa Bay Buccaneers in Super Bowl 37 while his newborn son was in hospital with fatal genetic disease; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Whereas Joe Jurevicius was consumed by grief at his last Super Bowl, in 2003 in San Diego, he is filled with gratitude in Detroit.
